have to say what what I believe psychological safety is and to me psychological safety is not to feel
comfortable all the time but to be comfortable even in uncomfortable
situations so that you can go into a situation where there's some sort of conflict or where there's people who
disagree on things and you have to do something for the first time and you can still feel okay with it to me that's
psychological safety and I agree that there's a huge overlap with how to do
good retrospectives there there are many ways of facilitating retrospectives but I am
aware that some ways are better than others which is why I wrote the book and
the thing about feeling safe in a retrospective is really important because the point with the retrospective
is that as a team you should share and appreciate and learn from what has
happened and if you if you don't feel safe you might not want to share the things that didn't go very well because
maybe you want to cover up that something went wrong you made a mistake or you were afraid or or sad about
something somebody said and also it's very difficult to appreciate what happened and with appreciate I mean both
appreciating in the positive and negative sense uh acknowledging that these things happened and it actually
didn't make us a better team and I think you're not really able to acknowledging that in honest unless you have the
safety and then the last thing about learning I think it's really important to to learn to feel safe and that's also
something that I apply a lot when I'm teaching at the university is that if the students don't feel safe to ask
questions if they don't feel safe to say there something they don't understand then it's very difficult to learn that's
that's really interesting so there's a couple of things that stuck out there for me the the first one around being
kind of comfortable almost being uncomfortable and that's something that
